abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the HIV/AIDS Disaster
            Response Project in Kenya were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, sustainability was likely, institutional
            development impact was substantial, the Bank performance was
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: 1) With
            respect to program coordination, Kenya HIV/AIDS Disaster
            Response Project (KHADREP) support to National HIV/AIDS
            Control Council (NACC) has been essential for the progress
            which has been achieved, and support should be continued
            under the planned new Project (TOWA). Future support should
            also be linked to the full implementation of NACC's
            institutional restructuring plan, and NACC's delivery
            of the specific results outlined in the Kenya National
            HIV/AIDS Strategic Plan (KNASP) 2005-2010 results framework;
            2) Attention should be paid to both the internal and the
            external domains of public sector programs when the emphasis
            of the work of the AIDS Control Units (ACUs) has been on the
            internal domain; 3) The role of the financial management
            agent (FMA) and the arrangements to mitigate concerns about
            inappropriate selection of projects and "briefcase
            NGOs" should be strengthened; 4) The lack of an
            effective programmatic monitoring and evaluation (M&E)
            has made it difficult to quantify the impact of the KHADREP.
            This is a lesson that applies not only to Kenya, but more
            generally to other countries fighting the HIV/AIDS epidemic;
            and 5) The KHADREP experience shows that the NACC needs
            leadership that is creative, results-based, effective in
            communications, collaborative and with complete integrity.
            In addition to the specific investments needed in such areas
            as financial management strengthening, internal oversight
            and audit, and the development of a fiduciary risk
            management policy, strengthening local decision-making,
            monitoring and accountability at the central and local
            levels, communications, it is also critically important that
            the newly recruited senior staff at the NACC should be
            trained and supported to enable them to function effectively.

repnme.cdata!:
Africa - Multi - Country HIV/AIDS Program
            for the Africa Region (Ethiopia and Kenya)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Multi-Country HIV/AIDS Program (MAP)
            for the Africa Region, will significantly increase access to
            HIV/AIDS prevention, care, and treatment programs,
            particularly by vulnerable groups - youth, women of
            childbearing age, and groups at high risk. The project is
            the first phase of the regional Program, covering Ethiopia,
            and Kenya, who have met the eligibility criteria for
            accessing funds under the MAP, developed comprehensive
            multi-sectoral strategic plans for the medium term, and
            endorsed the principle of public/private partnerships, to
            implement their national strategies, and assume overall
            program coordination. Each individual country project
            operation has their own specific development objectives, but
            provide the basis for this program. The program for Ethiopia
            will finance the Government's 2000-2004 HIV/AIDS
            strategic plan, that include support for capacity building
            within, both private, and government agencies. Prevention,
            care, and treatment activities will also be financed, to
            expand the public multi-sectoral response of civil society,
            and communities to the AIDS epidemic. The Kenya program will
            intensify the fight against AIDS, supporting five priority
            areas, that include prevention, and advocacy, treatment and
            support of the continuum care of AIDS affected people,
            management, and coordination, and mitigation of social
            impact, through research, monitoring, and evaluation.
